guide.title: Gentoo Weekly Newsletter
guide.subtitle: 22 January 2007
guide.abstract: This is the Gentoo Weekly Newsletter for the week of 22 January 2007.

body.p: While (un)fortunately gnash (a FOSS flash implementation) is still in its infant shoes, Adobe released the final version of flash player 9 for linux. While the questions about why they didn't include a non-debug plugin into the -dev tarball, we just inserted the upstream version into the tree. (Thanks to Jakub Moc and Olivier Crete, for taking care of it so fast.)

The gentoo Adopt-a-dev project has settled into a lack of interest lately. Thus we're reminding everyone about it. Developers need to ask for things, and the users. offer up something for the developers. For example, Diego recently needed a cheap soundblaster card with little in the way of requirements. This is the area where you can help out something specific like alsa.
We all use it but who would of guessed that it might be held up because of something like that missing...
Chriswhite recieved a book of perl from a user, who has helped him in testing maintaining and working with perl.

Once again, we need both the developers and users to request and offer up the resources that you might be able to donate. It might not seem like much but you'd be surprised how often a simple item turns out to be exactly what is needed.

That's right. As Dimitry Bradt joined up the gwn-team, we're restarting this developer-of-the-week chapter. You can always mail us about this using the following address: gwn-feedback@gentoo.org. That's why we're interviewing him for this week's GWN.
Chris, can you add the interview, along with this picture ? (http://dev.gentoo.org/~diox/foto/diox.jpg) thx; diox.
i (diox) haven't picked an article yet. Suggestions welcome ! Ping me at irc for that please.

Alexander Færøy, a contributor at the paludis project, wrote a blogpost about their new asset, which is http://planet.paludis.org. For the people living under rocks, Paludis is an upcoming alternative to Portage written in C++, offering improved performance, a more flexible configuration system and providing many much-asked-for features that were unable to be added to the Portage. The paludis developers started the planet-integration which is updated each 30 minutes, to meet the needs from the quick-growing paludis community.

Because most of the Paludis developers are also Gentoo Developers (and because Paludis is a cool package manager), Danny Van Dyk will give a talk about this package manager at Fosdem2007. He'll be explaining how people can simplify maintaining packages within a basic gentoo installation.

Last week, a few of us attended at the Linux Conference in Sydney, Australia. Attending devs were: Daniel Ostrow, Mark Kowarsky, Christian Marie and Daniel Black. They unfortunatly didn't have a booth, but though they did have a great time. The most fascinating talks were: keith packard's talk on RandR, Andrew Cowie's and Madely's talk on Gtk programmingand chris blizzard did a talk on OLPC.

That's right! Scale5x is comming up next. Besides the developers you can meet, which are listed below, gentoo is also attending a live showing of rocky horror picture show. You can find Gentoo at booth #63 (see the gentoo page on the official scale site).

On friday Scale is holding mini conferences which are titled: Women in Open Source and Open Source Healthcare. The real fun is only starting the day after that though. The event is held for 3 days, which is from February 9th till February 11th.
